Award.AbstractNarration:
GRADUATE TEACHING FELLOWS IN K-12 EDUCATION
ABSTRACT

PROPOSAL #: 0742434
PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR: Michael Jacobson
INSTITUTION: U Colorado, Denver
TITLE: Transforming Experiences: Interdisciplinary Teams of GK-12 Fellows Linking Teacher Professional Development, Middle School Implementation and International Collaboration

The Transforming Experiences GK-12 institutes a system that will enhance and strengthen the teaching and research of the chosen GK-12 graduate fellows. Through interdisciplinary teams, including science and mathematics fellows, university content faculty and middle school teachers, the project will create a process for transformation and simultaneous renewal of instruction based primarily on inquiry-based learning. The GK-12 fellows, with assistance from their faculty mentors, will serve as conduits to middle school classrooms as co-instructional partners for curricular and instructional development, advisors, mentors, and content and research experts. Additionally, global connections with an exchange of educational philosophies will be made as teams participate in regular video-conferences and possible visits with Chinese colleagues involved in developing a similar program.

By participating in this program, GK-12 Fellows will transform their understanding of teaching and learning, and leave with a new vision of how they, as higher education mathematics and science professionals, can interact, communicate and work effectively with the pre-collegiate community to improve P-20 mathematics and science education. Teachers and content faculty will gain a better understanding of mathematical and scientific learning and research that they can apply through problem-based learning in their future classrooms. Participants will experience first-hand the necessary skills of working as a team. Team members will also gain an appreciation of the cultural difference of the Chinese educational system, how it relates to the American educational system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The reporting period (06.01.14 to 05.31.15) reflects a second no-cost extension to complete use of remaining non-participant funds. With permission from the program officer, these funds were allocated to STEM outreach at the University of Colorado Denver (UCD). Specifically, a Community STEM Clubs (CSC) pilot program was implemented successfully in the spirit of the original GK-12 grant. That is, graduate and undergraduate students at UCD were provided scholarships and professional development to work with middle/high school students and develop exciting and innovative STEM outreach activities to a) improve their communication skills and b) provide positive experiences and role models in STEM. The CSC pilot led to the successful grant application for an NSF IUSE grant for after-school STEM clubs (awarded summer 2015 to UCD). 

Over the entire life of the award, the GK-12 grant at UCD has been able to positively impact the lives of graduate students, middle/high school teachers and students, and learning communities in the greater Denver areas. Specifically, graduate students have learned to communicate science and math more effectively to the general public, they have been positive role models in schools and encouraged students to consider STEM careers through the use of innovative approaches to teaching/learning in classrooms. Teachers have found these approaches to be relevant to academic standards and to improve student interest as well as achievement in science and math. Some of the lessons and activities developed by GK-12 participants continue to be used at the schools. Collectively, GK-12 participants have built long-standing learning communities invested in the personal and professional growth of STEM learners. These learning communities continue to collaborate today to improve STEM outreach, evidence that the UCD GK-12 program has had a lasting impact.
